item.title: Poll Shows Voters See Democracy in Peril, but Saving It Isn’t a Priority
item.description: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that other problems have seized voters’ focus — even as many do not trust this year’s election results and are open to anti-democratic candidates.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti, Michael C. Bender, Ruth Igielnik and Kristen Bayrakdarian

item.title: Today’s Politics Divide Parties, and Friends and Families, Too
item.description: In the latest poll by The New York Times and Siena College, nearly one in five voters said that politics hurt their friendships or family relationships.
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans and Alyce McFadden
item.media:credit: Phelan M. Ebenhack for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nelson Aquino, a moderate Democrat in Florida, said he’s fallen out with Republican friends and acquaintances over political views.

item.title: As Europe Piles Sanctions on Russia, Some Sacred Cows Are Spared
item.description: The European Union has been severing economic ties with Moscow to support Ukraine, but some countries have lobbied to protect key sectors.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Virginie Nguyen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rough diamonds, a lucrative export for Russia, are shipped to the Belgian city of Antwerp, an important diamond hub.

item.title: Drones Embody an Iran-Russia Alliance Built on Hostility to the U.S.
item.description: Authoritarian regimes in Moscow and Tehran have in common international isolation, domestic crisis and conflict with the West.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A drone believed to be an Iranian Shahed-136 nearing its target in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: After Roe, a Debate About What the Word ‘Abortion’ Means
item.description: In medical terms, the definition is clear. But when disputes arise, opponents argue that not every termination is an abortion.
item.dc:creator: Kate Zernike
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of abortion rights and anti-abortion demonstrators gathered in Indianapolis this year.

item.title: Sadder but Wiser? Maybe Not.
item.description: A landmark 1979 study found that depressed people had a more realistic view of their influence over events. New research calls that into question.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Allan Swart/Alamy
item.media:description: The experiment involved a button and an occasionally flashing light, and participants were asked to assess if they were making the light flash when they pressed the button.

item.title: Italy’s Next Government Hinges on a Familiar Face: Silvio Berlusconi
item.description: Giorgia Meloni’s likely turn as prime minister will depend on support from the billionaire media mogul. So may the health of Italian democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi, flanked by Matteo Salvini, left, and Giorgia Meloni at a rally for the right-wing alliance before elections last month.

item.title: Teacher at Center of Hijab Controversy Sues Olympic Medalist for Defamation
item.description: After a New Jersey second-grader told her mother that her teacher had tried to pull off her hijab, the story went viral on social media.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully

item.title: How Credit Suisse Became a Meme Stock
item.description: The longstanding troubles of Credit Suisse recently grabbed the attention of amateur investors whose social media posts sparked fears that the bank was running out of money.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell, Emily Flitter and Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Lea Meienberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Credit Suisse headquarters in Zurich. The bank, founded in 1856, is a storied Swiss institution.

item.title: NLCS: Philadelphia Embraces Bryce Harper as Leader of Phillies
item.description: Bryce Harper is on a roll for the Phillies, and is deeper into the playoffs than he has ever been. The bond between him and his team’s home city continues to deepen.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Bill Streicher/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: As the Philadelphia Phillies celebrated their win over the Atlanta Braves in Game 4 of their division series, Bryce Harper made sure to acknowledge the fans at Citizens Bank Park.

item.title: NLCS: Manny Machado Has Been a $300 Million Bargain for San Diego Padres
item.description: Manny Machado is a star on and off the field, and his unflinching presence, day in and day out, helped lead the Padres past the Dodgers and into the N.L.C.S.
item.dc:creator: Scott Miller
item.media:credit: Kyle Grillot for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manny Machado hit .357 and played spectacular defense at third base for the San Diego Padres in their division series with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

item.title: Ralph Macchio Will Always Be ‘The Karate Kid.’ He’s Finally Fine With That.
item.description: His new memoir, “Waxing On,” sees the ’80s star making peace with the role that has brought him back into circulation thanks to “Cobra Kai.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Cannariato
item.media:credit: Tonje Thilesen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A seemingly ageless 60 years old, Ralph Macchio has written a memoir about how “The Karate Kid” changed his life.

item.title: Britain’s Liz Truss Is Finished
item.description: Britain’s prime minister may limp on, powerless, but she will fall.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Gold
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Daniel Leal, via Getty Images

item.title: The U.S. Thinks ‘It Can’t Happen Here.’ It Already Has.
item.description: We don’t need foreign models to understand America’s authoritarian tendencies.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Capitol on Jan. 6, 2022.

item.title: Preparing for Republican Debt Blackmail
item.description: Democrats should do whatever it takes to block extortion.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: The Fall of Liz Cheney and the Rise of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: The Jan. 6 hearings were the final hurrah for Decent Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
Weapons of Mass Delusion: When the Republican Party Lost Its Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor Greene, ascendant in the Republican Party.

item.title: Reindeer Dog vs. the Swedish Tax Agency
item.description: Indigenous Sami tradition vs. Swedish bureaucracy — who wins this dogfight?
item.dc:creator: Maria Fredriksson

item.title: A Legendary World-Builder on Multiverses, Revolution and the ‘Souls’ of Cities
item.description: How the fantasy and science-fiction writer N.K. Jemisin thinks about people and difference in our complex world.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Welcome to the Madness of Our Trumpy, Trumpy World
item.description: How much will the Supreme Court change the world?
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Grutter v. Bollinger’s affirmation of affirmative action may well be the next precedent to fall.

item.title: Power in the N.F.L.
item.description: The owner of the Washington Commanders has survived numerous allegations in the image-conscious N.F.L.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Geoff Burke/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

item.title: Did Hurricane Ian Bust Florida’s Housing Boom?
item.description: The insurance market in the state, which underpins the real estate sector, could be facing its greatest shock in decades.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Michael Simon Johnson, Carlos Prieto, Diana Nguyen, Mooj Zadie, Paige Cowett, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A home damaged by Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla. Data now makes it clear that Ian is part of a trend: Climate change is making hurricanes and other disasters more destructive.

item.title: Behind Oz’s Crime Attacks Is a Play for the Philly Suburbs
item.description: An impeachment vote against Larry Krasner, the Philadelphia district attorney, points to the potency of an issue that works against Lt. Gov. John Fetterman.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Laurence Kesterson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Supporters of Dr. Mehmet Oz in Malvern, Pa., in Chester County on Saturday. Oz, the Republican Senate nominee, and allied groups are spending millions of dollars on ads attacking Lt. Gov. John Fetterman.

item.title: George Saunders on ‘Lincoln in the Bardo’
item.description: The writer, celebrated for his short stories, discusses his 2017 debut novel, and the journalist Patrick Radden Keefe talks about “Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland.”

item.title: In the Netherlands, Balancing Energy Security Against Climate Concerns
item.description: A central location and web of gas pipelines are helping boost gas imports in the country even as it tries to stick to its clean energy goals.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eemshaven harbor in the Netherlands. When Russia invaded Ukraine, Dutch officials understood the role the Netherlands could play in mitigating the energy emergency.

item.title: What to Know About the New NBA Season
item.description: Much of the conversation around the league the past few months hasn’t been about basketball.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Steven Senne/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Boston Celtics stand for the singing of the national anthem before playing against Golden State during last season’s N.B.A. finals. Both teams have been navigating internal crises.

item.title: The Search Is on for Mysterious Banana Ancestors
item.description: A new study shows that domesticated bananas have genetic markers tying them to three types of wild bananas that have not yet been found.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Beatrice Sirinuntananon/Shutterstock
item.media:description: Imagine if you had all of these bananas to pick from every day.

item.title: James A. McDivitt, Commander in Early NASA Triumphs, Is Dead at 93
item.description: In the 1960s, he led the first spacewalk mission and took part in the first crewed orbital flight of a lunar module.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.media:credit: NASA
item.media:description: James A. McDivitt, right, and Edward H. White 2d inside their Gemini 4 spacecraft awaiting liftoff in June 1965. The highlight of the four-day mission was a pioneering spacewalk.

item.title: How to Stay Safe From Covid This Holiday Season
item.description: As our third pandemic winter approaches, you can mitigate risk without missing out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How to Get Rid of Bad Breath
item.description: Food choices, oral hygiene habits and certain health conditions can play a role — but there are ways to keep dragon breath in check.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Pablo Delcan; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: ‘Kind of Awkward’: Doctors Find Themselves on a First-Name Basis
item.description: While many physicians may avoid discussing the subject, a study showed that who gets addressed with the honorific “Dr.” may depend on gender, degree and specialty.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Use of formal titles in medicine and many other professions is a linguistic signal of respect and professionalism,” two doctors wrote.

item.title: Björk, Still Using Style to Captivate
item.description: A look back at some of the artist’s best looks over the years, as she releases her 10th studio album, “Fossora.”
item.dc:creator: Indya Brown
item.media:credit: One Little Independent Records
item.media:description: Björk, in the video for her song “Ovule” off her new album “Fossora,” wore a dress designed by Gucci’s Alessandro Michele.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
